content: It may be that the second account is attempting to use the SMTP server of the first account. you can check that by - click 'account settings' - highlight the account that doesn't work in left sidebar - now, in lower right side of screen, click the button for 'edit outgoing server' and see if it is the same email address as the account. if not, revert to prior screen and select the dropdown menu of outgoing server and select the appropriate SMTP server.
creator: davidsk

content:
I am unclear on you situation. If you have a newer PC, you can transfer 100% from the old to the new with these steps:

  1. start thunderbird on old PC
  2. click tools>export and then click 'open profile folder'
  3. exit thunderbird
  4. copy profile content to external media
  5. install thunderbird on new pc, downloaded from thunderbird.net
  6. in receiving PC, click help>troubleshootinginformation
  7. scroll to 'profile folder' and click 'open folder'
  8. exit thunderbird
  9. now, paste contents of exported profile, overlaying contents of profile.
  10. if there is a compatibilitie.ini file, delete it
  11. restart thunder

if The old PC was a POP account and you just want to copy some of the messages to a different PC, that is also possible. Please clarify you intent. Thanks
creator: davidsk

content:

Thank you for your help! Susan C.H.

content: The add-on "Folder Colors" is no longer compatible with recent Thunderbird versions. You can customise the colours of folder icons: R-click on the folder > Properties > General Information > Icon Colour
creator: Mapenzi

content: Account colors have never been part of the standard Thunderbird code and I have no idea whether this is planned in a near or a distant feature. It certainly would be a useful feature for many Thunderbird users, otherwise the old, now abandoned add-on Account Colors addons.thunderbird.net/fr/thunderbird/addon/account-colors/ wouldn’t have had such a success. If you like you can vote for this feature on this webpage https://connect.mozilla.org/t5/ideas/color-for-thunderbird-accounts/idi-p/14758
creator: Mapenzi

content: Thanks for the reply . I've just cast my vote for it.

content:
First, this is a peer-to-peer forum. That is, we have no authority on new features. If you wish, you can go to connect.mozilla.org, and click to the IDEAS section for Thunderbird and record your recommendation there. On your issue, Thunderbird is more complex, but it offers more options than all other email clients. One key feature is that you can set the font for your preference, yet not force recipients to see your font instead of their own preference. I did a summary of steps in a prior post, so I am including a link here to it. It may be useful. Let me know if any issues. 

  https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1462509
creator: davidsk

content: I was glad to assist. I agree, it is time-consuming, and I used thunderbird for years before I figured those steps out. But they free you completely for fonts. :) No, you were not offensive, just a tad frustrated. I understand completely. Enjoy.

content: Assuming you are using Windows, look at menu item Tools | Settings | General | Incoming Mails. Play with the "Show an alert" settings to get what you like. You probably just need to uncheck "Use the system notification".
creator: rednoise

content:
This works. It's more steps, but it works. - create a single email address in the addressbook, populated with all the fields that you would normally use. - then, export that addressbook to csv - now, open in a spreadsheet and review the top row for column names. - next, load your outlook csv in spreadsheet and adjust to match the sample that you downloaded. - save as csv with comma-delimited. - this csv should now import with the column names that work.

Question: important, really. When you import the csv, do you see a prompt that shows the columns available and how to match? Please see attached screenshot. My concern is that the intent of that prompt is to allow users to adjust column names. If you are not seeing it, then we may have a bug. thank you
creator: davidsk

creator: khablow

content:
I'm not clear about what your intent is. If you want to extract addresses from all the messages in a local folder and add them to an address book that can then be exported to a CSV file, it can be done with the aid of the alternative address book, "Cardbook".

https://addons.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/addon/cardbook/

- Create a new local Cardbook address book

- Create a Message Filter for Local Folders like shown in the attached image, where the criteria is "Age is greater than 0 days" (to select all messages in the foler); action is "Add From to Cardbook" (you can also choose To, CC, and BCC addresses).

- Select the local folder in question and run the filter against it.

The receiving Cardbook Address Book will have all addresses, including duplicates, so it may need some grooming. Cardbook includes a de-dupe tool.

I expect there are other ways to do this, and you may not want to install Cardbook for just this operation. Since I already use Cardbook, this is how I'd do it.

If this isn't your goal, please clarify.
creator: rednoise
